Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Extreme Precipitation in the Northeast United States in Observations and Models
Award.AbstractNarration:
Extreme precipitation and its related impacts, especially flooding, result in significant loss of life, property and infrastructure damage, transportation disruption, and storm water pollution, and have economic costs of more than $8 billion per year for the US. This project will undertake fundamental research into understanding the causes of extreme precipitation in the Northeast US. This is the most economically developed and densely populated region of the country. Improved model representation of these processes is a crucial step in the overall goal of improving forecasts and projections of these high-cost events, thereby mitigating their impacts.

Processes that cause extreme precipitation over daily to weekly periods in the Northeast US will be identified. The ability of current climate models to reproduce these processes will be examined. The two motivating questions are: What types of storms cause extreme precipitation in the Northeast? Do current models correctly reproduce these storms types and their relationship to extreme precipitation? Using observational data, storm types associated with extreme precipitation will be identified by applying advanced analytic techniques. Characteristic patterns in the jet stream and other storm features that occur in association with extreme precipitation will be identified. This analysis will then be undertaken on the climate model output to identify the storm types that are produced in the models and compare the modeled types to the observed types. The differences will be highlighted for use in model development and for providing context for model forecasts and projections. The physical processes by which the extreme precipitation are generated within each storm type will also be investigated. The relative strength of different factors that are known to influence precipitation, such as the amount of moisture in the lower atmosphere, will be examined within each storm type. After the key factors are identified, their influence will then be further tested in a regional, high resolution model by changing the strength of individual factors and examining how the modeled precipitation changes in response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on understanding the causes of extreme precipitation in the Northeast US and assessing how well they are represented in current climate models, which is important to our ability to understand and predict these types of events.  

We started by developing a method of separating the events based on their regional circulation patterns, which we then used to distinguish between different types of storms. This allowed us to develop a clearer picture of the underlying causes, which are different for different storm types.  Understanding the causes of extreme events is not only scientifically interesting but also important to improving short-term weather predictions.  Assessing how realistically climate models are able to represent those causes is important as context for considering projections of possible future changes. In order to assess how confident we are in projected changes in extreme precipitation, we need to understand how well the models used to make the projections are producing extreme precipitation in the right places for the right reasons. Additionally, the techniques and data developed in the project to examine the causes of extreme precipitation in the Northeast US can also be used to look at other types of events in other regions, and so the work supported here also serves as a useful starting point for addressing other problems.

Figure 1 shows the circulation patterns for the six different types of storms that regularly produce extreme precipitation in the Northeast US, as identified in this project. The patterns are shown in terms of tropopause pressure, which is a useful variable for describing the regional circulations.  The contour lines show the pressure, with red shading indicating where the tropopause is closer to the surface, and blue shading indicating where the tropopause is farther from the surface. The tropopause defines the top of the troposphere, the lowest layer of the atmosphere which contains most of our weather, and up-and-down movements in the tropopause are an important part of most regional-scale weather systems. The height of the tropopause is also closely linked to the position of the jet stream, which is shown as a red arrow for each storm type. While extreme precipitation always requires both strong rising motion and a large supply of moisture, this range of different storm types shows that there are multiple different ways in this region of producing both factors, including different pathways for moving moisture into the region and different ways of causing strong rising motion. Current climate models are able to reproduce some of these patterns but struggle with others, especially C1, and there are clear differences between models.

NSF support for this project has resulted in improved scientific understanding of extreme events, training and professional development of the next generation of scientists, and communication of the results to both specialists and broader communities of public interest. The project has produced scientific papers describing the results; research training and professional development for graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher, including members of groups underrepresented in the sciences; information provided to international and local climate assessments; publicly-available computer code; and a set of techniques and data that are easily applied to other problems. We are currently exploring the application of the project results to investigating the short-term predictability of extreme precipitation events, making projections of extreme precipitation that account for model strengths and weaknesses in representing regional storm types, and analyzing regional heatwaves.
